Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Langevin Subgrid Scale Closure and Discontinuous Galerkin Exascale Large Eddy Simulation of Complex Turbulent Flows

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1603131/1603589/1604142
Givi/Mavriplis/Girimaji


Turbulent combustion is encountered in nearly all energy conversion devices, such as internal combustion engines, gas turbines, boilers, and gas burners. Turbulent combustion involves many complex physical and chemical phenomena. The ability to predict accurately the turbulent combustion process is critical to the design and optimization of combustion devices for achieving low emissions and high efficiency. This research will develop accurate computer models and numerical algorithms that can reveal the fundamental turbulent combustion processes and allow industry to design clean combustion devices, thus benefiting the environment. Extensive code development and computer simulations will be conducted. Additionally, this project will also include numerous education and outreach activities, including the development of an Interdisciplinary Computational Science Minor to provide additional courses on high-performance computing, student training in the multidisciplinary field of Computational Modeling and Simulation, K-12 outreach through the INVESTING NOW and CAMP-SOAR programs, and recruitment of students from minority and under-represented groups through the EXCEL program.

In an effort to increase the accuracy of turbulent combustion simulation, this award provides funding to develop a new Langevin subgrid scale (SGS) closure and to implement it with a new discontinuous Galerkin numerical scheme for large eddy simulation (LES) of turbulent flows. The former provides accurate modeling of the SGS transport for a wide range of turbulent flows, including compressible and chemically reactive. The combined methodology will be put together in a package in which the available computational cores are utilized in a dynamic, adaptive manner. This is an important concept in high performance computing necessary for massively parallel simulations up to petascale, and towards (future) exascale. The new LES tool will be employed for predictions of several turbulent flows. The computational requirements for the proposed LES, in its most sophisticated form and utilizing the highest intended resolution, will be several orders of magnitude less than that required for direct numerical simulations. When successfully completed, this research will have a significant impact on turbulent combustion research. It will be extremely valuable for both industry and government agencies. The outcome of this work can also positively impact other disciplines, such as climate and atmospheric modeling or bioengineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapidly increasing speed of modern supercomputers has increased the use of computer simulations to further our understanding of complex phenomena such as high speed reacting flows. High speed reacting flows are relevant in surprisingly diverse fields of science and engineering ranging from turbulent combustion in modern propulsion systems to turbulent nuclear flames in Type Ia supernovae. Using the next generation supercomputers (Exascale) for scientific discovery requires that the physical models and the numerical methods make efficient use of the Exascale computing resources.

The physical model (Large Eddy Simulation (LES) with a Dynamic Subgrid-Scale model) and the numerical method (Discontinous Galerkin (DG) Finite Element method with split form kinetic energy preserving fluxes) developed, implemented and tested in this project enable efficient use for Exascale computations of high speed lows. The LES method is a physical model that provides increasing accuracy with increasing resources by resolving more and more of the turbulent scales and modeling less. In the limit of sufficient resolution, the LES method converges to a "model error free" simulation method. To numerically solve the LES equations in a computationally efficient way, requires high order accurate numerical methods such as the DG method. However, LES is typically under resolved (i.e. some scales have to be modeled) and high order numerical methods are prone to suffer from aliasing effects that result in numerical instabilities of the computations. The split form DG with a kinetic energy preserving flux method removes the aliasing issues without introducing excessive numerical "friction" which would dampen the smallest resolved scales and thus reduce the accuracy of the LES. It can also be combined with adaptive mesh refinement to increase the resolution only locally where necessary (see figure 1).

By combining the DG-LES method with the high fidelity Langevin model for the subgrid-scale effects of mixing and chemical reactions we obtain an efficient method for Exascale computations of high speed reactive flows. The Langevin model is a stochastic model for the unresolved subgrid-scales that predicts the statistical moments such as the mean and the variance with a high accuracy. The statistical ensemble is represented by a collection of numerical particles in each computational grid cell. This is shown in figure 2 which shows simulation results from a turbulent flame colored by the reaction progress.      

The DG-LES method developed in this work is relevant to other disciplines as well. We are currently applying the DG-LES method in simulations of a large collection of wind turbines to predict the reduction of power output due to "shielding" of the turbines located farther downstream by the upstream turbines.
